content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a differentiable function such that <math alttext="f of 3, equals 2.345" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2.345</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f prime of x, equals, the natural log of, open parenthesis, x squared, plus 1, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the value of <math alttext="f of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 6.7: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and Definite Integrals
